Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Civic Participation and Insurgent Mobilization in Deeply-Divided Societies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

Nascent insurgent organizations have routinely benefitted from tapping into the membership networks of activist associations, recruiting politically aware and committed individuals to swell their ranks in relatively short order. Yet the relationship between activism and insurgent mobilization is not well understood. This project seeks to explain how insurgent movements work to undermine activists' commitment to their organizations, and why certain civic organizations are more vulnerable to rebel recruitment drives than are others. It also traces how activists who do leave peaceful forms of activism for violent rebellion might leverage personal and professional relationships with other activists and their beneficiaries to bring greater numbers of individuals into the insurgent fold, thereby transforming the resources of civic activism into the resources for violent rebellion. In so doing, this project will provide guidance to activists and policymakers wishing to protect and promote the development of civil society in deeply-divided societies at risk of, or already experiencing, violent internal conflict.

Technical Summary

Based on nine months of in-depth fieldwork comparing Maoist recruitment efforts amongst ethnic organizations during Nepal's civil war (1996-2006), this research will assess a number of factors that impact activists' commitment to their organizations, and thus each organization's relative vulnerability to rebel recruitment efforts. Relying primarily on semi-structured interview and focus group testimonies with activists and beneficiaries, as well as with former insurgents, the project will examine how factors such as the scope and type of an activist organization's activities, its structure, and the material rewards of activism impacted activists' commitment to their organizations. It will also assess how insurgents chose organizations and activists to target for recruitment, and how they worked to undermine existing commitment. Finally, this research will trace how initial activist defections to the rebel group may have triggered cascades of defection through organizational networks as other activists and beneficiaries sharing ties with early defectors followed suit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two questions were at the center of this project. First, how do peaceful civic associations working for social and political change retain the commitment of their activists when insurgent organizations are trying to recruit those activists into violent rebellion? Second, why are some of these associations more vulnerable to rebel recruitment than are others? To answer these questions, the co-PI conducted nine months of fieldwork in Nepal comparing Maoist recruitment efforts during the civil war (1996-2006) across four separate ethnic associations operating on behalf of the highly marginalized Tharu community in two different districts. We interviewed approximately 120 Tharu activists, former Maoist insurgents and recruiters, and expert observers from human rights organizations and academia. We analyzed the various activities in which the Tharu associations were engaged, their organizational structures, the political leanings of the associations’ leadership, and the pay and other material incentives they offered to their activists to determine the factors most responsible for activists’ decisions to leave peaceful activism for violent rebellion.

 We found that activist associations are best able to generate and retain the commitment of their activists during wartime when the activities they are engaged in provide activists with a sense that they are contributing to the uplift and advancement of their co-ethnics both in the immediate locales in which they operate and as a broader community in general. Put differently, activists want to feel that their efforts are making a meaningful difference both locally and supra-locally, in the lives of neighbors and imagined kin they have yet to meet. Activists almost uniformly expressed aspirations to contribute to the uplift of their co-ethnics in their villages as well as in their broader community that spanned the country. When activists feel that their work is contributing to improvements in the lives of their co-ethnics locally and more broadly, they feel a sense of pride and efficacy that sustains their identities as activists and strengthens their commitment to their associations. When these aspirations go unfulfilled because their activities are unable to produce any real change, activists lose pride in their work and feel that their very identities as activists and contributing members to their societies are undermined. This leads them to look for other ways to contribute to their community’s well-being, which provides an opening for insurgent recruiters to bring them into rebellion.

 Interestingly, even localized activities such as village-level infrastructure projects or informal education classes for women can provide activists with a sense that their efforts are all scaling up to extra-local level advancements for their ethnic kin. For example, village-level literacy classes allowed graduates to approach area- and district-level government offices to demand a more equitable distribution of resources so that Tharu communities would suffer less from exclusionary neglect when budget funds were being allocated for development projects. Even activists whose work was largely limited to their own villages felt that the aggregate benefits of their efforts were not limited to their immediate environs alone. This enhanced activist commitment to their associations and left some organizations less vulnerable to losing their activists to rebel recruitment.

 There is one important caveat that conditions the dynamic outlined above. If insurgents begin to abuse civilians over time either by physically beating and killing them or by stealing from them and destroying their property, even activists who are unhappy with their work or who actually sympathized with the insurgents’ goals at one time will be unlikely to support the insurgents. Activists typically aspire to contribute to the uplift and advancement of marginalized groups. Supporting organizations that abuse civilians directly contradicts these aspirations and violates their identities as individuals who contribute to the betterment of society and the lives of others.

 In sum, we find that the activists and, by extension, the civic associations that are most vulnerable to rebel recruitment are those that engage in activities that provide little to no advancement for the communities on whose behalf they work. This may not be altogether surprising. Nonetheless, it represents an important lesson, particularly for the practitioners and supporters of peaceful civic activism in societies at risk of conflict. We know that activist associations have become hotbeds of recruitment for violent and non-democratic movements in many places across history, ranging from 19th-century France through the Nazi seizure of power in Germany to late 20th-century El Salvador. However, little work has been done to analyze how such associations become vulnerable to rebel recruitment or why some are more vulnerable than others. This research represents an important development in our understanding of these issues and provides actionable lessons for associations looking to insulate themselves from rebel recruitment efforts now and in the future.
